Uhm those aren't train lines specifically, those are stations, train routes and train types mixed. Do you need seating pics of Frecciarossa? Frecciaargento?

In Italy there are two national train companies: Trenitalia, the public one, that runs several types of trains (Frecciarossa -the fastest- Frecciargento, Frecciabianca -slightly slower- generally referred as Le Frecce, Intercity, Regionale -slower but with more stops, so if you need to go to a smaller city you’ll probably want one of them) or Italo, the private company (only fast trains named Italo, very few lines).
Then there are some small local trains like Malpensa express, Circumvesuviana
or small local companies like Trenord (only in Lombardia).

I have planned strike questions. I hope someone who lives in Italy or has lived through strikes in Italy will have the answers!

I don't understand quite how they work. There are two planned strikes for when we will be in Italy. One is a rail strike that affects Italo, nation-wide. Naturally, we are scheduled to travel that day. The other is air traffic controllers, nation-wide.

The rail strike is scheduled for September 17-18, beginning at 3:00 AM on the 17th until 2:00 AM on the 18th, so 23 hours. We will be traveling at 8:30 AM on the 18th. Does this mean the trains will be backed up? How do we find out if our train will go that day at all if they are backed up?

The second strike is for what I think is air traffic controllers on September 16 from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM, although I don't think this one will affect us (but not positive) as we land at 11:30 AM on September 17. In this case, do planes just not take off from or for Italy that would be landing during the time period of the strike since there is no traffic control? I'll assume it will back up traffic for a day or two?

We don't typically experience this level of strikes in the US with such regularity, so I'm not sure of how stikes like these work or affect travel, locally and nationally. BTW, there are a LOT of planned strikes for local transportation all over Italy for September. You may want to check the strike calendar, just be sure you have Google translate on so you can read it properly--put in dates that would affect you. text: Hello! I have never been to Italy before but I’m trying to plan a surprise trip for my partners birthday! I have lots of questions haha I’m thinking 4/5 days, I think there’s more that interest us in Rome but also want to go Venice to go on a gondola, is it possible to do a couple days in each? Can anyone recommend a nice hotel in the city centre of either? And any things that are a must see/do in either of these places? Thank you ☺️

comments.comment_text: From Roma you can easily take a fast train to Venice, but with 4/5 days only I would not advice you to do both.

Three nights Rome and two in Venice would be enough to see major sites and have some great memories. That said, you're biggest expense will be airfare, so if you're already paying that, then consider adding a couple of days to spend more time in either city or add Florence.
I would do only one place like Valentina suggested
I did that too for my parents long time ago 🙂. They visited Rome and Florence… was amazing trip they say.
do one city only in your 4/5 days ...
If you are planning a “surprise” be aware that this is a public group, meaning even if your partner is not part of this group if he/she has Facebook she/he could see it

Take a few more days..traveling
takes up 2 days. I recently went and was counting on flights being ontime..it just doesn't happen that often. The plan was to arrive at 8 a.m. and flight was delayed almost 4 hrs...half flights were canceled that day so we were lucky to take off at all. So we really only had half a day on our first day. Coming home,more hourly delays and then returning to ewr had to stand on line 40 minutes to show our passports to get back into U.S.. So my advice is, don't play it too close with your scheduling.

There is so much to see in Rome. I’ve done a lot of research on things to do and places to go. I’m going with a tour group that’s doing Italy in 14 days. They are only spending one day in Rome. They are doing the Sistine chapel, Vatican museums, St Peter’s, the Colosseum and the Roman Forman. One day is not enough. So, I’m going 5 days early. I’m going to do the Hop on Hop off bus for 3 days and 1 evening. I’m going to download Rick Steves free audio tours. I’m also going to do a nighttime food golf cart tour. They have scooter tours, tipsy tours and shopping tours. Just look on FB. Plus, I plan on doing a lot of walking to just explore.

Many rooms to choose close to Pantheon, it's centered between Piazza Novella, the Vatican, St. Peters, the Colloseum, Trevi and the Spanish steps. You'll be very very busy in Rome, would normally recommend at least 5 nights in Rome, in your case, 3 and 2.

I know time and budget may be limited but if you are traveling from US or Canada I honestly could not image going to Italy for the first time for only 4/5 days especially trying to do more than one city. I would never do it if your flight was not direct either, we have delays both ways.

4/5 days is not enough to see Rome & Venice as Venice is in the North part of Italy & Rome in the South. You will spend too many hours traveling. I would save Venice for a future trip & visit Rome with a day trip to Amalfi Coast, a day in Rome, & then go to Florence.

And remember you will both have jetlag! That made our schedule wonky for a few days. I came from Canada. I agree with those who recommend a longer trip, particularly given the cost of airfare. Of you only have 4-5 days pick another place closer to your home...
4-5 days, plenty to do in Rome. The gondola will always be there as it's a tourist thing.
Everyone’s different but with only 4 or 5 days I’d spend the whole time in Rome.

You can catch the fast train from Rome to Venice. You can definitely see a lot of both cites in that time. My favourite of the two is Venice. I normally get a train around 9-10am to go to the next city. That way I get up, have breakfast and go to station. You won’t get caught up somewhere and risk not making your train.

text: Buongiorno a tutti. I am looking for some recommendations/advice. I am planning on going to visit family in Asiago, Italy in late November/early December. The closest airports to Asiago are Bologna, Verona, Venice or Milan. We are not planning on renting a car and will be travelling by train or bus from the airport to Asiago. I am looking for suggestions as to which is the best route to Asiago, that has some nice points of interest to stop along the way, between the airport we land in and Asiago. Thanks for your time.

comments.comment_text: Check rome to Rio app from all those cities. It will show all.of your options

The best route to Asiago from the four airports you mentioned depends on your interests and budget. Here are a few options:

Bologna: This is the closest airport to Asiago, and it is also the most affordable option. You can take a train from Bologna Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2 hours.

Verona: This airport is a bit further from Asiago than Bologna, but it has more flight options. You can take a train from Verona Porta Nuova station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2.5 hours.

Venice: This airport is the furthest from Asiago, but it is also the most popular tourist destination in Italy. You can take a train from Venice Santa Lucia station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3 hours.

Milan: This airport is also a popular tourist destination, but it is not as close to Asiago as Bologna or Verona. You can take a train from Milan Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3.5 hours.

If you are looking for a route with some nice points of interest to stop along the way, I would recommend flying into Bologna and taking the train to Asiago. You can stop in the town of Vicenza, which is known for its beautiful architecture.

You can also stop in the town of Marostica, which is known for its annual chess tournament that is played in the streets.

If you are flying into Verona, you can stop in the town of Verona, which is home to the famous Verona Arena.

If you are flying into Venice, you can stop in the city of Venice itself, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

So.. have been planning my dream Italian trip for months . 8 months to be exact. I always wanted to go to Italy. I was so looking forward to going to this country with my two kids and husband .

We were all ready , packed and with only 4 hours left for the flight my son started having severe stomach pain. Rushed him to the ER , he had to have appendix surgery and we came home 2 days later .
Missed the flight , all but one airbnbs returned 50% . All of the attraction tickets I bought through official websites do not have any cancellation option so I will have to start calling them tomorrow . Only cancellation that happened was via Viator .
I don’t know how to feel. I am extremely relieved that my son didn’t get sick in the air or in Italy but I am so extremely lost now with what to do next.
Bought my plane tickets through a third party and they are of no help when I tried to reschedule. I am constantly on the phone . As of now they are saying don’t be hopeful on the air ticket refund. I will keep trying .
Had so much fun planning this trip.. this group was nothing but wonderful. Just wanted to share my story here .please keep my family in your prayers .

I’m so sorry that happened to you. Always get travel insurance! You never know what will happen. The night before we were scheduled to come home, my son got the flu and had a fever of 104. There was no way he was getting on a plane. We took him to a hospital and they said he couldn’t fly for five days. There was no charge at the hospital and they gave us a note that he couldn’t fly. I called the airlines right away to cancel our flight and see if they could get us on another one. The trouble was it was the week between Christmas and New Years and all the planes were full! Finally they got us on one New Years Eve but had to bump us up to business class because all the other seats were filled. When I got home I contacted our travel insurance company and they were great! They covered the balance on our airfare and even asked if I had receipts for the extra nights for rooms and food! We stayed with friends so we didn’t have any extra expenses but they were ready to cover those too!

While you may not get a refund, you may get credit to use your tickets to book a different trip. The typical caveat is you need to travel before the 12 month expires - and often the 12 months is from when you made the original reservations - not the departure date.

I’m so sorry this happened to you. I can imagine how disappointed you are.

But as someone who was involved in a life threatening accident in Rome that required hospitalization
and surgery I have to say I’m glad his problem
happened here instead of in Italy. To be honest, I received excellent medical care there and they saved my life. But it’s very frightening and psychologically
difficult to deal with a medical system you’re unfamiliar with. And where you maybe aren’t fluent with the language. (I can say some common phrases in Italian but medical terms were beyond me.). Then there’s the financial aspect. Before leaving the first hospital I had to pay 24 thousand Euros for my stay of three days plus surgery. The second hospitalization
which lasted two full weeks was additional. I can’t even begin to tell you how stressful it would have been to face those worries in a foreign country on top of concerns for your sons health.

On the bright side, as I said before, I was treated very well by the doctors and hospital staff. All of my hotels were extremely cooperative and refunded my non refundable payments in full. I hadn’t expected that but was certainly happy they did it. I had purchased flight insurance which covered my missed flight back home. I was also lucky in that my home medical insurance reimbursed me in full for the amount I had to pay the Italian hospitals. And my insurance also paid for a first class flight ticket to get me home as well as paid for a nurse to accompany me.

So although you were unlucky with what happened, in another way you were lucky it happened before your trip not while you were on it.

Here’s what I learned from my own experience.
1. Buy medical insurance for each trip. Most US policies do not provide for the reimbursement mine did. But you do need to have coverage while abroad.
2. Buy flight insurance. It’s cheap
but so important if something happens.
3. Be sure any insurance you have provides for evacuation home.
4. Always book directly with the provider (the airline or the hotel itself, for example) because the third party is just another layer of bureaucracy you have to deal with if something goes wrong.
5. Stay in a fully staffed hotel not a vacation rental. The help provided by the hotel staff was invaluable to me. From going with me in an ambulance, to making arrangements to extend my husband’s longer than intended stay at reduced rates, to making phone calls for us I honestly can’t imagine how we’d have navigated the situation without their kindness and help. They did so many things, both little and big, to help
us out during our nightmare. I’ll be forever grateful to all of them.
6. Take along an extra high limit credit card to be used only in case of an emergency.

None of this will help you right now. But I wanted you to know you’re not alone in having had a trip ruined by medical issues. I’m proof that anything can happen so I hope passing on what I learned might somehow help to prevent struggles in the future.

And of course, I hope your son is fine and healthy now. That’s really the most important thing.

We are staying three days in Rome before a cruise and found a great AirBnB.
In my experience a “double” in Europe is often two singles(twins) put together or closer to a queen size. They are larger than a typical American “double/full” sized bed.

Yes, it is still too crowded near the Trevi Fountain to stay in a hotel near there in early November. The fountain is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Rome, and it is always crowded, even in the off-season. If you are looking for a reasonably priced hotel with access to public transportation,
I would recommend staying in a hotel in a less crowded area, such as Trastevere or the Monti neighborhood.

And also yes, queen and king size beds are not as common in Europe as they are in the United States. The standard bed size in Europe is a double bed, which is about the size of a twin bed in the United States. However, there are some hotels that do offer queen and king size beds, but they may be more expensive.

Here are some reasonably priced hotels in Rome with access to public transportation:

Hotel Forum: This hotel is located in the historic center of Rome, near the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. It has a metro station right outside the door, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

Hotel Raphael: This hotel is located in the Monti neighborhood, a short walk from the Trevi Fountain and the Spanish Steps. It has a bus stop right in front of the hotel, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

Hotel Santa Maria: This hotel is located in the Trastevere neighborhood, a lively and charming neighborhood with a lot of restaurants and bars. It has a metro station within walking distance, making it easy to get around the city. The hotel has a variety of room sizes, including double, twin, and family rooms.

I hope this helps!

comments.comment_text: That's a very subjection question, depending on what your likes are personally. We are going to Florence, Rome, and Amalfi region. We fly into and out of Naples. If you're a museum and art person, then Florence. If you like architecture and ancient history, Rome. If you're going for the sea and scenery Amalfi or Cinque Terre. If you love rolling hills and beautiful landscapes, Tuscany. Honestly, can't see how you can go wrong in Italy. I've not seen any pictures on this group from anywhere in all of Italy that haven't been breathtaking. Enjoy! Good luck!

You're very well situated to visit Venice and Florence, but also, take advantage of the region you're in: if you're a foodie, Modena and Parma are easy to get to, and on the coast you have Ravenna as well...have a great trip!
From Bologna with fast train you can easily go to Florence, Venice, Milano, and Rome. South of Italy would be a bit distant.

I would be careful with Parma though. Had a bad incident some years back (we were almost attacked by a group of 10 youngsters ) and recenmy friends car was mugged there (glass broken, things stolen). But all the other towns mentioned are amazing 🙂

Florence, Venice, Verona, Padova, and you could try also to get to the Southern parts of Lake Garda like Sirmione - you are well situated to see all those cities and also to enjoy Bologna which is a great city!

Rhona OConnor

Thanks for all the great comments! We chose Bologna because it’s so centrally located and easy to get to other cities, but we have such a limited amount of time, so the real question is, WHERE should we go? We are not as much into churches and historical sights as we are foodies and would love to shop and explore quaint neighborhoods. So if you only had a handful of days to travel from Bologna, where would you absolutely want to go?

That sounds like a great trip! Here are a few "must go" cities in Italy that are a short train ride from Bologna:

* **Florence:** The capital of the Tuscany region, Florence is home to the world-famous Uffizi Gallery and the Accademia Gallery, where you can see Michelangelo's David. Florence is also a great city for wandering around and exploring the narrow streets and alleyways.
[Image of Florence, Italy]
[Image of Uffizi Gallery, Florence, Italy]
* **Siena:** This beautiful medieval city is known for its Piazza del Campo, a large square with a shell-shaped fountain. Siena is also home to the Leaning Tower of San Gimignano, a 14th-century tower that is one of the most iconic landmarks in Italy.
* **Pisa:** This city is home to the Leaning Tower of Pisa, which is one of the most recognizable landmarks in the world. Pisa is also a great place to visit if you are interested in history and architecture.
* **Modena:** This city is known for its balsamic vinegar and its Ferrari museum. Modena is also a great place to visit if you are interested in food and wine.

If you are interested in art and history, I would recommend visiting Florence and Siena. If you are interested in food and wine, I would recommend visiting Modena. And if you are interested in seeing a unique landmark, I would recommend visiting Pisa.

No matter which cities you choose to visit, you are sure to have a great time in Italy!
